She is requesting for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase generator as alternative power supply and deep freezer for sales of cool drinks so that she meet up with the increasing number of her customers and make more profit.  She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase generator and deep freezer for business

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato B. is a married twenty-three year-old from the village of Sta. Cruz. To make a living, Renato owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Renato has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately PHP10,000 a month for these activities.

This year Renato joined PMPC to gain access to financial services in order to improve his living situation and business. Renato is requesting a new loan of PHP 25,000 that will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Renato from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Devotha

texts.en:
Devotha is a member of the Gangilonga borrower group in Kinyanambo , Iringa. She is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 14, and 4 years old.

Devotha has owned a business for 3 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Devotha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Devotha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for sale

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa D. Jesús M. D. P. resiD. en Sensutepeque en el departamento D. Cabañas. Teresa  vive solamente con sus cuatro hijos, ya que su esposo se encuentra trabajando fuera del país. Teresa extraña mucho la unión D. su familia y es por eso que se esmera mucho en su negocio para que su esposo regrese al hogar que lo espera. Teresa tiene una tienda D. productos D. consumo, la cual quiere surtir por medio D. este crédito.

loans.use: Surtir su negocio

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena E. is from the village of Zone 7 Bobontugan, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old. Lorena is single and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Lorena owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Lorena has been engaged in her business for over 2 years.

In 2008, Lorena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Lorena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Chashma Salar Group

texts.en:
This is Chashma Salar group which has four female members. These women would like to progress and develop their businesses.

Afghan Gul is the group leader and she has a bakery business in her house. She has run this business since the Taliban regime when all women were confined at home and there were no jobs and schools for them. Now, with the loan, she wants to buy more materials for her business to bring a new change in her business and to make progress.

Zahera wants to receive a loan for her husband who has a general store. Her husband wants to buy more things which he needs for his business.

Sorai wants to take a loan for her carpet-weaving business. She wants to buy better materials for carpet weaving and wants to progress her business and be able to support all her family members.

Sakina wants to receive a loan for her tailoring business. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her business because she has lots of problems with the old one when sewing. Besides that, she wants to hire a student to support him in her business and enlarge her business.

Freshta wants to receive a loan for her husband's taxi business which needs a new part.

So they have together requested a group loan of 50,000 Afghani and they would like to say Kiva is the best loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her bakery business

loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
Angie B. is from the village of Colupan Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 19 years old. Angie is single. 

To make a living, Angie owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling electronic loads, which are devices used to test electronic circuits for items like power supplies, batteries, solar and fuel cells, and generators. Angie has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Angie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angie is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Voice Of Women Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Voice of Women group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni city who want a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve on their living standard. 

Adama F. in the middle is the leader of this group. Adama is now age forty-seven. She was born in Makeni and is  a widow with six children. Two of her children are already adults, three are in secondary school, and one is in class six. 

Adama sells market foods such as Maggi (used to give sauce a good flavor), salt, onions, tomatoes etc. wholesale. With her share of the loan, she will add more goods to her business. She will buy more cartons of Maggi, more bags of salt, onions, and tomatoes.

(Attached on the right is the snapshot of a group member who was not present for the group photo).

loans.use: Buy the goods she sells wholesale

loans.name: Ravza

texts.en:
Ravza P. is 55 years old. She is married with two children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has two cows and two calves. Now Ravza wants to expand her business, and as her children are grown up she thinks that she will be able to look after more cattle with their help. So she is asking for $1200 USD in order to purchase cattle. Ravza expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Maria Angelica

texts.es:
Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga.
Maria es casada, tiene 39 años y 4 hijos, Maria tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, carne, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hijos.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la ampliación de su local.
Los sueños de Maria son que sus hijos sean profesionales, su negocio sea surtido y tener mas ventas.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Alegría Huamanga Microfinance Institute.

Maria is a 39-year-old mother with 4 children. She runs a store from home in which she sells general goods, vegetables, and meat every day with the help of her children.

Maria needs a 1,250.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in expanding her business space.

Maria dreams of her children becoming professionals, of having a well-stocked business, and of boosting sales.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business space expansion

loans.name: Desideria

texts.en:
Desideria R. is 54 years old and is a fish vendor. She sells fish daily in her village to raise money for buying food, clothing and other basic needs for her family. She started her fish-selling business in 1972. 

She would like to grow her business more. With a small loan from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc., she will be helped in realizing her dreams. She will be able to obtain more fish to re-sell and earn a better income.

loans.use: Obtain more fish to re-sell

loans.name: Ebson

texts.en:
Ebson K. I. currently owns a small trolley from which he sells sausages in the town of Thika, Kenya. He sells to local people of all types and ages. Currently he is self-employed, but his goals with the loan from SMEP are to purchase additional trolleys to rent out to other people to generate additional income. 

Ebson, his wife, and 2 kids have no other source of income in the household, and he also states that an additional challenge is harassment from the local city council due to his business being located in an open air market. Eventually, Ebson would like to start a restaurant business. He describes himself as kind, patient, humble, and says he loves people.

loans.use: to purchase additional food carts to rent out to other people

loans.name: Kasfa,

texts.en:
Kasfa is 45 years of age and she is married with seven children. She rents a one-room house where she lives with her children. She also takes care of her grandchild.

Her greatest expenses in a month are feeding the family and paying rent for the house. Kasfa sells ripe bananas in the market. She receives about ten customers a day. She has operated this business for several years now. Her challenges are the price fluctuations for commodities which in turn force her to raise the prices of her bananas. 

Kasfa has been with MCDT for over three years and this is her 7th loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas to sell, and she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell

loans.name: Elsa Lapinig Group

texts.en:
Elsa L. is from the village of Tipolo, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Elsa is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elsa L..

Elsa is single. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Elsa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Dolores' Group

texts.en:
Dolores D. L. is from the town of Villa Marzo Cordon. She is forty-three years old. Dolores is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Dolores D. L.'s group.

Dolores is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Dolores owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. She used this previous loan to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be Dolores's fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-nine branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Malemin Group

texts.en:
Nazya is the group leader of the Malemin group. She lives in the 15th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has four children. She is a tailor and works hard to earn money to meet her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her shop because she has lots of problems with the old one when sewing.

In addition, she wants to hire a student to support him through her business and to enlarge her business. He wants to take out an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani. She is very glad that she has the chance to progress.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her shop

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen P., 37 owns a sari-sari store owner and is a farmer from Banga Agusan del Sur.  She started her business in 1996 and uses her income to help educate her three children.  Her oldest child is in high school.  She dreams that someday her children would be able to finish their studies.  Helen would like a loan of Php 15,000 to buy more merchandise to sell.  Helen joining the CEVI credit program in 2009.  CEVI gives insurance coverage to all the members.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Ramón R. esta casado con la señora Silvina Jara  ellos tienen 2 hijos menores  y viven en la casa de sus padres.
Ramón   tiene un pequeño negocio de fabricación de tapa junta de motor, el trabaja con su padre  de quien aprendió  este oficio y  necesita de este crédito para la compra de materia prima en cantidad por los pedidos  que tiene . 
El trabaja con su señora quien recibe los pedidos y también hace las entregas ,mientras Ramón y su padre realizan  los trabajos.
En el futuro desea comprar un vehículo para las entregas  de sus productos y de esa  manera  cumplir mejor con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ramón R. is married to Silvina Jara and they have two minor children; they live in his parents’ house. Ramón has a small business making metal moldings for vehicle motors; he works with his father who taught him this skill. He needs funds to buy raw materials in quantity to fill his pending orders. He also works with his wife who takes orders and makes deliveries while Ramón and his father manufacture the parts. In the future, he’d like to buy a vehicle to use for deliveries so that he can provide better service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy metal and paint.

loans.name: Mrs. Ny Chab Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan is for eleven people who are villagers in Manong Leu village in Prey Veng province. Mrs. Ny C. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use a portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Ny C. and her husband, Mr. Ngey Khat, are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice to sell in order to support their family. Their problem is that the soil in their field is infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Ny C. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. She also intends to use part of the loan to buy some piglets to start a new business. The piglets will be used for breeding. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory. The other is attending a local public school. All the members are included in this photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and piglets

loans.name: Gelevazio

texts.en:
For over a decade, 43-year-old K. Gelevazio has been depending on his banana plantation in Kabwoma village, Rukungiri, to earn him income. This has been his major source of livelihood though he has also been making a side-income working as a security guard in Rukungiri Town.

By Gelevazio’s own admission, it’s his devotion, hard work and determination which has been his requisite stock in trade. He is an optimist who believes his prospects for the future for his family and his businesses are up to the mark.

Gelevazio is happily married with six children, all going to school. He took over this business from his late father. In a month, he makes profits that sum up to 150,000 shillings.

With this loan, Gelevazio is looking at rejuvenating his banana farm. He wants to buy more banana stems to plant on a larger scale.

loans.use: To purchase more banana stems to plant on a large scale

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie B. is from the village of Baliangao. She is 44 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Lenie owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling of dry goods in the local community. Lenie has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 2,900 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lenie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lenie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Lenie is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for the store. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Lenie from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for the store

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort F. is married to a carpenter and takes care of six dependants. She buys fresh fish and smokes them for sale in Abura. Comfort helps her husband meet the basic needs of the family with the income she makes from her sales. Comfort will add the loan she is going to received to her own capital to enable her to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. Comfort plans to reinvest in her business, should there be any form of increase as a result of the loan.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima B., from the village of Unidos Plaridel Misamis Occidental, is 60 years old and married. To make a living, Maxima owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, and candies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Maxima joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC that was used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory, she is now requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Maxima plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia S. is 57 years old. She is a busy entrepreneur and wishes to be able to help her children and provide a decent life. She makes and sells ice cream products and closely works with her husband as an ice cream vendor. She started the business 12 years ago to help her family meet basic needs as everything is very expensive. 

She will use the loan to buy more ingredients for her ice cream products, so she needs more capital to meet the demand in her customers in the local area where she sells her ice cream. She is pleased because, in the past, she has managed to utilize the loans to invest in her ventures.

With working capital Cecilia’s business will continue growing and she will be able to provide good service to her regular customer. Through the support of KIVA lenders, Cecilia hopes to see herself and her family, who currently live in poverty, soon change their quality of living, 

Cecilia’s long-term goal is to have an ice cream booth a few years from now so that she can give an opportunity of employment to others specially her extended relatives in their community. Cecilia hopes to maintain a long-term sustainable ice cream business. 

During her 12 years as a member of ASHI, Cecilia has shown very good performance with her group mates and center. Having this loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a successful business, fund the educational needs of her children until they finish college, and have a better life and a happy family as well. Cecilia is very thankful to ASHI and KIVA for the continued support of her dreams.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her ice cream products

loans.name: Hilario

texts.es: Hilario tiene 32 años de edad, está casado y tiene dos hijos; Jhon y Yoselin, de 7 y 3 años respectivamente. Juntos residen en la localidad de Quimbiri, ubicada en la ceja de la selva peruana, donde tienen su propio techo a base de madera. En un principio, cuando se inició en la actividad agricola, cultivando y comercializando café, no lo estaba yendo, tal como él se lo había imaginado. Pero como a él le gustan los retos, no le tuvo miedo a lo que se venía, es así que insistió y se intensificó en esta labor, hoy produce cantidad de café, que son distribuidos a sus compradores asiduos. Se siente muy contento por lo que viene atravesando, incluso sus ventas aumentaron con respecto a los anteriores meses. Por lo general trabaja  con su esposa y juntos laboran de manera colectiva, pero en temporada de cosecha, tiene a cargo de sus peones, con la finalidad de que les pueda facilitar la extracción de su producto final, siendo estos vendidos en los centros de acopio de su misma localidad. En el futuro, Hilario anhela comprar un lote de terreno, en la ciudad de Huanta, con la finalidad de que pueda construir su casa y con el tiempo pueda alquilar cuartos, ello lo generaría nuevos ingresos económicos. Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con sus respectivos pagos, tal como lo hizo en los anteriores préstamos, además está satisfecho con su banco comunal, debido al buen comportamiento y compromiso de sus socios. Con el crédito que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de insumos y abono, con la finalidad de que pueda preservar la calidad de sus plantaciones de café.
texts.en:
Hilario is 32 years old, he is married and has two children, Jhon and Yoselin, aged respectively 7 and 3. They all live in the Quimbiri settlement, located at the edge of the Peruvian rainforest, where they own a wooden house. At first, when he started engaging in the agriculture activity of planting and selling coffee, things were not going as he had imagined; but as he likes challenges, he did not worry about the future and, insisting on it and intensifying this activity, he now produces a good quantity of coffee that he sells to his regular customers. He is very happy about his success, and his sales have increased compared to the previous months as well. His wife generally works with in team with him, but for the harvest season he contracts laborers, in order to more easily crop his final products, that are to be sold to the local collection centers. In the future, Hilario wishes to buy some land in the town of Huanta, in order to build a house for his family and to be able, in time, to rent rooms, as this would generate new incomes. This is his fifth loan with MFP, and he commits to keeping on repaying his dues, the same way he did with his previous loans; he is also satisfied with his communal bank because of its members’ commitment and good behavior. He will use the loan he is requesting to buy materials and fertilizers in order to preserve the quality of his coffee plantations.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to protect his coffee plantation.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more crushed rocks to sell

loans.name: Jose Leonzo

texts.es:
el señor Jose Leonzo J. P. tiene 52 años de edad, es padre de cuatro hijos y se dedica a la venta de pescado y camarones, tiene 8 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad.
sus ventas las realiza en Nacaome y Agua Fria en su bicicleta, coloca un termo en la parte de atras y ahi lleva el producto y cuando viaja a nacaome las ventas las realiza en bus ya que esta bien largo de donde el vive.
 
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de pescado blanco, rojo y camarones con el fin de aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Jose Leonzo J. P. is 52 years old and he is the father of four children. He sells fish and shrimp and he has had 8 years' experience in the field. 

He carries out his sales in Nacaome and in Agua Fria, travelling on his bicycle. He places a thermos on the rear part of the bicycle to transport the product to Nacaome. He also uses the bus to complete his sales because he lives very far away.

The loan will be used to purchase fishes and shrimp with the goal of increasing his income.

loans.use: To purchase fish and shrimp.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma A. has successfully repaid her first Kiva loan. With the loan she financed the increasing customer demand on her fishing and resale of frozen foods businesses. She is so thankful for your support and for the opportunity to borrow money from Kiva. She wishes to access a larger loan to expand her businesses so that she can increase her turnover. Norma thanks KIVA for providing her with opportunity to increase her proceeds. Your support is very important to her family and they pray that all supporters be blessed because of their good hearts for the poor people around the world.

She is requesting a much larger loan of 25,000.00 Php to support her businesses. Norma has noted that her monthly income has almost doubled since she has attracted new customers with additional inventory.

With the support of ASHI and Kiva partner, she is hopeful that her business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life. Norma still dreams of supporting her children in their schooling until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: to maintain her fishing business and resale of frozen foods business.

loans.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna A. is a young woman married to Ismael and a mother of six daughters and two sons. The family own a small rabbit farm where they raise rabbits for sale. Muna came to FATEN and asked for a loan in order to purchase more rabbits and feed to answer the increased demand, as Al Adha feast is coming soon.

Muna, her husband and one of her sons work on the farm, while the rest are school students. Muna and her husband aim to increase returns and enlarge the farm, especially because they are a big family and Gaza has a lot of farms, which increases competition.

Muna's husband appears on the farm in the picture here since the conservative background Muna comes from prevents her from having her picture online.

About Shariah-compliant lending:
 
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To purchase rabbits and feed

loans.name: Rwenyonyozi Tukore Group

texts.en: T. Wellen belongs to the Rwenyonyozi Tukore group. He is 39 years old and married with 5 children, 4 of whom are in school. Wellen has an agricultural business, selling matooke (a type of banana), beans and coffee. He is helped by his brother and is able to make a monthly profit of 80,000 UGX. He is also involved in building houses as another source of income. Wellen needs a loan in order to purchase and resell more bananas for increased profitability. He is a very hardworking and cooperative man. His future plan is to further reinvest in his produce business and to educate and care for his family.

loans.use: to purchase and resell more bananas

loans.name: Pangkung Liplip Indah Group

texts.en:
Ni Kadek S. is a 28 year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali.  Ni Kadek is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Pangkung Liplip Indah (PK-10387).


Ni Kadek is married and has two school-aged children.  To making a living, Ni Kadek owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale.  Ni Kadek has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month from these activities. The most fun part of this effort is to see pigs eat their food with gusto, so that they can grow big. Later, they can be sold at high prices.


In 2010, Ni Kadek joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Kadek has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,500,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Kadek plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children.

She is pursuing this business because she wants to help the family finance their children's schooling. She wanted her children to be educated up to college.



About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Kadek S. (0) merupakan 28 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Kadek adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Pangkung Liplip Indah (PK-10387).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Kadek sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 2 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Kadek menghasilkan sekitar 0,200 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Kadek bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Kadek telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1.500.000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membE. bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1.500.000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Bernardina Santos

texts.es:
Bernardina, reside en San Miguel, departamento de San Miguel, se dedica a la venta de frutas tiene 33 años de edad, vive con su hija de 12 años de edad llamada María Nicolasa, el negocio es vender las frutas preparadas sin cascara y cortada en trozos.
Bernardina tiene la necesidad de un préstamo para comprar frutas como manzanas, naranjas, sandias, melones y poder realizar la venta, ya que en ocasiones se queda sin frutas. Este préstamo le ayudara a mantenerse con el negocio y a generar para su hija los ingresos necesarios para cubrir sus necesidades. 
Su objetivo es mejorar el negocio, invertirle para que sea más estable y ayudar a su hija en la superación de sus estudios.
texts.en:
Bernardina lives in San Miguel, which is in San Miguel Department.  She sells fruits.  Bernardina is 33 years old and lives with her 12-year-old daughter, María Nicolasa.  Her business is selling fruits that she has peeled and cut into pieces.

Bernardina needs a loan to buy fruits like apples, oranges, watermelon and melons so she can sell them because sometimes she runs out of fruit.  The loan will help her to keep the business going and generate the necessary income to take care of her daughter's needs.
 
Her goal is to improve the business and invest in it so it can be more stable and she can help her daughter do well in her studies.

loans.use: Purchase fruits like apples, oranges, watermelon, melons

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny J. is an Industrious and business-minded young mother. She is 26 years-old from Villar, Sibalom, Antique Philippines. She is living with her partner in life, Romel Samillano, and they are blessed with one child (John Emmanuel).

While their child is still young, she wanted to earn more in order to have savings for the education of their children.

Despite some difficulties she never gives up especially in fulfilling her responsibilities as a mother and as a member of Kiva partner ASHI. She has performed well because she wanted to use a house repair loan in order to renovate their house so that it is comfortable for them.

At present, she is asking for a new loan in the amount of  PHP 9,000.00 which she plans to use to provide additional capital for her pig raising business.

She hopes that someday  through the help of ASHI and its field partners, she will be able to take a larger loan so that they will have more income in order to sustain their needs. She wants to give a bright future for her child.

loans.use: Hog fattening

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein M. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. Hussein has a small retail shop, which he has run for five years. He also owns rental houses.
To help expand his business, Hussein has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items, such as sugar and soap, for resale. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Hussein hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his child. In the future, Hussein hopes to improve his family's standard of living by meeting basic needs at home.

loans.use: To purchase more items, such as sugar and soap, for resale

loans.name: Long's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Long C. was born in 1974. She earns her living by selling fish in the village. In order to support and enlarge this business, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more fish to sell. She will use the rest of the loan to buy chickens for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Khut Boramy, is a teacher who is able to earn a small salary to support the family. This couple has three children: two are students and also support their mother's business, and one is 3 years old. 

There are eleven members forming this village bank loan. They are from Kampong Tuol village. Mrs. Long C. is the village bank president selected by the other members.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: This is 34 year-old Rita P..  She is unmarried and has two children. In 2000, Rita P. established her food business. She opens her business five days a week and nine hours a day. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 in order to buy more food items for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 700,000. In the future, Rita P. plans to open another business so that her younger ones will be running it for her. In the future she hopes to build a house for her family.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin Q. is a a cattle farmer. He has earned a living from raising cattle since he was young. He buys small calves in the livestock bazaar, fattens and raises them, and then sells them at a profit. He has 6 years of experience in the business and knows his job very well. Elchin has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase two calves.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene L. is from the village of Babahagon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 49 years old. Rene is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rene owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods,  shampoo, soap & instant noodles in the local community. Rene has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rene is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy has been in the farming business for 11 years with more concentration on bananas, maize, and milk in the Nkubu area, Central Kenya. She is married with three children aged 21,16 and 8 years old and all schooling. She relies on farming for the family upkeep.

Mercy has made a third loan request of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to carry out an expansion of her banana plantation acreage and buy more poultry. Her first and second loans of 30,000 and 50,000 KES respectively were promptly repaid.

Mercy says lack of water for irrigation and animal diseases remain her farming challenge but is optimistic with all her businesses.

loans.use: To pay for expansion of her banana plantation and buy poultry.

loans.name: Nueva Amistad De Huascar Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL NUEVA AMISTAD DE HUASCAR

Clemencia es una persona muy trabajadora que ha conseguido todo lo que tiene gracias a su propio esfuerzo y trabajo, ella se dedica a la venta de artesania, las cuales algunas las compras y otras ella misma las produce, tambien ha enseñado a sus hijas este negocio, ahora cada una de ellas elabora sus propios productos, Clemencia usara el prestamo para comprar insumos y materiales para sus artesania, y sueña con ver su negocio mas grande, incluso desea exportar sus productos y hacer que sus productos sean conocidos

Clemencia es tesorera de la alcancia comunal NUEVA AMISTAD DE HUASCAR, cuyo nombre es porque son vecinas y han mostrado union, solidaridad entre ellas, trabajan con EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD por 5 años, y cada quien en su respectivo negocio ha decidido crecer y ser mas productivo.
texts.en:
NUEVA AMISTAD DE HUASCAR [New Friendship of Huascar] COMMUNITY BANK 

Clemencia is a hardworking person who has obtained everything she has thanks to her hard work and effort. She sells artisanal crafts. She buys some of them and makes some of them herself. She has also taught her daughters this business and now each of them makes her own products. Clemencia will use the loan to buy materials for her artisanal crafts. She dreams of seeing her business grow. She even wants to export her products and have them be well known. 

Clemencia is the treasurer of the NUEVA AMISTAD DE HUASCAR community bank. Its name is due to the fact that the members are neighbors and they have shown themselves to be close and supportive to each other. They have worked with EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD for 5 years. Each person in her respective business has decided to grow and be more productive.

loans.use: to buy materials for artisanal crafts

loans.name: Ingrid Janeth

texts.es:
INGRID JANETH 
La señora   Ingrid   tiene 2 hijos menores de edad. se  dedica a la venta de sandalias  y joyas de fantasía  ella inicio hace 2 años  de manera ambulante en el mercado Local de su comunidad  ahora ella tiene el deseo de seguir superando en su negocio  con la ayuda de su esposo   han tratado de colocar un local donde ella vive pero aun falta todavía el techo para su local, y algunas cosas para  variar su mercadería y tener  más tipos  de numeración y estilo de sandalias  su mayor sueño ahora es  poder terminar su local   para poder atender a su clientela en su localidad    y con mayor comodidad   y así ya no salir a vender  de  manera ambulante.
texts.en:
INGRID JANETH 
Ingrid has two dependent children.  Her business is selling sandals and costume jewelry.  She started her business two years ago, making her sales as an itinerant street vendor in the local market in her community.  Ingrid would like to continue making progress in her business.  With the help of her husband, she has tried to set up sales premises where she lives.  However, she is still lacking a roof for her premises and some more products so that she can vary her merchandise and have different sizes and styles of sandals available.

Ingrid's biggest dream is to finish building her premises so that she can serve her customers in her town more comfortably.  This will mean that she will no longer have to go out and sell her products on the streets.

loans.use: to buy sandals to sell

loans.name: Silvia Ayde

texts.es:
Silvia  es socia del Banco Comunal “Trenzas de Oro” ubicado en el distrito Ilave, provincia  El Collao y departamento de Puno, tiene 23 años de edad, está casada y tiene un hijo.  Tiene educación secundaria.
Su primer préstamo fue de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invirtió en su negocio compra y venta de animales  vacunos. Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace dos ciclos.
Con este nuevo préstamo de S/. 1200.00 nuevos soles, aumentará al capital de su negocio y comprará un toro. Trabaja en el negocio junto con su esposo.
 Su sueño es seguir con el negocio y mejorar sus ingresos.
Lo que le  gusta del Banco Comunal es la puntualidad y la facilidad del préstamo.
texts.en:
Silvia is a member of the “Trenzas de Oro” [Golden Braids] community bank, located in the Llave district, province of  of El Collao and departament of Puno. She is 23 years old, married, and has one son. She has a high school education. 

Her first loan was for S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles. She invested the money in her business buying and selling cattle. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for two cycles. 

With this new loan of S/. 1200.00 nuevos soles, she will increase her business' working capital and buy a bull. She works in the business with her husband. 

Her dream is to continue with her business and improve her income. What she likes about the community bank is the ease of taking out loans.

loans.use: to buy a bull.

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en:
Priscah is 32 years old. She is a married businesswoman who supports a family of four members. She has been running her business of second-hand clothes for the last three years.

This is her first loan of 17,000 Kenyan shillings from KADET LTD. She plans to purchase assorted bales of skirts and T-shirts for sale. 

This will help boost her business and she will use the proceeds to expand her business and settle her family by the purchase of a residential plot.

loans.use: to buy bales of skirts and t-shirts for sale.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer.

Emelia cooks kokonte, a staple made of cassava flour and sometimes plantains, at Elmina. She has done this for 12 years. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. 

Emelia will use the loan to purchase cassava flour and other ingredients to prepare kokonte for sale. 

She plans to plow her profits back into her business for further growth.

loans.use: to purchase cassava flour and other ingredients to prepare kokonte for sale.

loans.name: Mujeres Al Poder Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó a través de las Sras. Maria y la Sra. Liz, quienes se habían acercado hasta la oficina de la Fundación Paraguaya para interiorizarse más del Programa de Mujeres Emprendedoras, las mismas invitaron a sus amigas y vecinas del Barrio y decidieron sumarse al trabajo grupal para salir adelante y así mejorar su estilo de vida, son 21 mujeres trabajadoras y humildes que deben ganarse el sustento todos los días.
La Sra. Liria se dedica a la venta de calzados desde hace ya un tiempo, ha logrado tener una gran cantidad de clientes que siempre compran de ella sus productos. Le gustaría algún día poder abrir una tienda donde vender sus calzados, ya que actualmente el espacio con que cuenta es muy reducido.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de más tipos de zapatos, ya que así podrá atraer a más clientes. Desde ya agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que le brinda, ya que sabe que le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
This committee was formed by Maria and Liz who approached Fundación Paraguaya's office to find out more about the Committee of Entrepreneurial Women program.  They invited their neighborhood friends and decided to start working as a group in order to get ahead and improve their lifestyle.  These are 21 hard-working and humble women who must earn a living every day.

Liria has been selling footwear for some time.  She has managed to gain a large number of customers who always buy their products from her.  Some day, Liria would like to be able to open a store where she will sell her shoes.

Liria is requesting this loan to buy more types of shoes since, in this way, she will be able to attract more customers.  She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity they are giving her.

loans.use: Compra de calzados para la posterior venta

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 40 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has six children. 

Erlinda has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, & beverages. She has had this business for 12 years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) to buy more of the items her store sells.

Erlinda is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Erlinda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks

loans.name: Mónica Carmita

texts.es:
La Señora. Mónica es socia del banco comunal Yanbal, vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad que es de clima frió, es reconocida por ser la tercera ciudad más importante  del país, cuenta con una gran variedad en su gastronomía, su gente mantienen su cultura y tradiciones.
 
Doña Mónica tiene 44 años, es casada y ha concebido 3 hijos de 23, 22 y 16 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos estudian en la universidad y trabajan, su último hijo estudia en un colegio de la ciudad.  Su esposo es chofer profesional y labora conduciendo un bus que es de su propiedad, no tienen casa propia y viven arrendando.

La Señora. Mónica labora en un comedor y esta actividad la desempeña hace 3 años, trabaja de lunes a sábados desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde.

Es socia de la banca comunal hace 3 años y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la matricula del colegio de su hijo y en útiles escolares.
 
Su sueño es tener casa propia.
texts.en: Mónica is a member of the Yanbal community bank and lives on the outskirts of the city of Cuenca. The city has a cool climate and is recognized as the third most important city in the country. It has a wide variety of cuisines, cultures and traditions. Mónica is 44 years old, married and has three children, ages 23, 22 and 16. Her eldest two sons attend a university and work, and her youngest son goes to school in the city. Her husband is a professional driver and works driving a bus he owns. They don't have their own home so they rent. Mónica has worked at a restaurant for the past three years. She works Monday to Saturday from 7 a.m. until 5 p.m. She has belonged to her community bank for three years, and with this new loan she plans to buy school supplies for her youngest son and and pay for his tuition. Her dream is to have her own home.

loans.use: to purchase school supplies and pay for tuition.

loans.name: Yeni

texts.en:
Yeni is a 34-year-old widow. She only has one son namely Dayat, 7 years old, who is studying in the fist grade of elementary school. 

Yeni runs a kiosk business by renting a small room nearby her house. She sells candies, biscuits, snacks, instant noodles, detergent, soap, shampoo, cereals, milk and beverages at her kiosk. She has been engaged in this business for seven years. 

Yeni wishes to improve her business by selling petrol and mobile phone recharges and adding more stock such as rice, sugar, coffee, cooking oil, etc. at her kiosk.  To do so, she is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000. She hopes that TLM will assist her in making her dreams come true.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, coffee, cooking oil, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. She sells cloth at Ayensudu near Elmina, which she has done for seven years. Abena uses her income to assist her husband in taking care of the home by feeding the children. She will use the loan to purchase more cloth to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abena plans to save to build a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth to sell.

loans.name: Fauzia Mvembo

texts.en: Fauzia is a married woman. She has a son who is 3 years old. She describes herself to be a good listener, obedient, and transparent. She operates a hairdressing salon where she provides hair care services. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located near a railway station. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of security in the market centre. She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to purchase hair care equipment and products. Her business goal is to relocate the business closer to the town centre to increase the number of customers within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be able to employ people as her business expands.

loans.use: To purchase hair care equipment and products

loans.name: Magda Grelia

texts.es:
Magda Grelia tiene 37 años de edad es soltera no tiene hijos vive en el Cantón Chillanes Provincia de Bolívar.

La VRC Unión y Progreso la Colombia baja, está conformada por quince integrantes y está ubicada a 90 minutos de la cooperativa esta ventanilla se dedica a Actividades Agrícolas, siembra de cacao, arroz, maíz, Soya plátano, naranja, etc.

Magda  se dedica a la agricultura, a la siembra de cacao arroz, maíz, soya, naranja  las compras y las ventas lo realiza en San José del Tambo cada fin de semana.

 Solicita el crédito para poder comprar semillas, abonos e insumos para los cultivos y también invertir en la compra de pollos para la cría y luego venderlos. 

Con la ayuda del préstamo le ayudará a suplir necesidades económicas, Enfrenta desafíos que son muy frecuentes como la competencia y las plagas. 

El sueño es poderse comprar una casa para poder vivir tranquila.
En los tiempos libres le gusta salir de paseo a visitar a los padres.
texts.en:
Magda Grelia, 37, is single with no children.  She lives in Chillanes Canton in the province of Bolívar.

The Unión y Progreso La Colombia Baja Communal Bank has 15 members and is located 90 minutes from the cooperative.  This communal bank is devoted to agricultural work, growing cacao, rice, corn, soybeans, bananas, oranges, etc.

Magda works in agriculture, growing cacao, rice, corn, soybeans, and oranges.  She buys and sells every weekend in San José del Tambo.

She is requesting the loan to be able to buy seeds, fertilizer, and crop supplies, and also to buy chickens to raise and then sell.  The loan will help her supply basic economic needs.  She confronts frequent challenges such as competition and disease.

Her dream is to be able to buy herself a house to be able to live peacefully. In her free time she likes to go out and visit with her parents. 

In her free time she likes to play with the children.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer, and crop supplies, and also chickens to raise and then sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter wants a loan to buy the local brew for resale. Aged 42 years, he hails from the Kyenjojo District in Uganda. He is a father of four children whom he lives with together with their mother in a semi-permanent house. Having started by distilling alcohol by himself, he saved money and he now buys from others -- a business that has grown over 21 years. His dream is to build a permanent house and increase his sources of income by venturing into the cattle trade.

loans.use: to buy the local brew for resale.

loans.name: Sonia Magdalena

texts.es:
Sonia D. 44 años, una mujer que tiene aspiraciones D. crecimiento en su negocio.
Su negocio es una tienda que está ubicada en L. parte delantera D. su vivienda.
Inicio su negocio con L. ayuda D. su hermano, ahora mantiene este negocio con L. ayuda D. su esposo.
L. dificultad D. elL. es L. delincuencia ya que fue víctima D. un robo a su  negocio.
Tiene dos  hijos uno 15 y 12 años, ambos están en escueL. públicas.
ElL. solicita el préstamo para el tratamiento médico D. su mama ya que elL. esta delicada D. salud.
Su sueño es incrementar su negocio  adecuar su vivienda ya que aun no está terminada.
texts.en:
Sonia is 44 years old and she is a woman who aspires to increase her business.

Her business is a store which is located in the front portion of her house. She started our her business with the help of her brother but she currently maintains the business with the help of her husband.

The difficulty she faces is delinquency and she has been a victim of theft of her business.

She ahs two children, aged 15 and 12, and they both attend public schools.

She requests a loan to for the medical treatment of her mother who is ill.

Her dream is to increase her business and to condition her house as it is still not completely finished.

loans.use: to cover medical expenses and to purchase medicines.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es: Victoria, de 39 años de edad, es una mujer muy trabajadora y amable. Vive en compañía de su conviviente y de sus cuatros hijos en su casa propia, que logró construírlo con mucho esfuerzo. La actividad que realiza Victoria es la compra y venta de granos como el maíz, lo adquiere en volúmenes mayores y los vende al instante a los almacenes. Esta actividad lo realiza en el puerto fluvial, donde espera la llegada de la lancha fluvial de los productores, a los que compra sus productos a bajos precios. Tiene un año dedicandose a esta actividad, que con ayuda de su pareja, van en busca de nuevos clientes. Lo que le gusta de su actividad es que le permite tener un ingreso económico con el cual pueda solventar los gastos de su hogar, manifiesta que también le gusta el trato con diferentes personas que le compran su producto. Sin embargo la mayoría de ventas lo hace a crédito y hay veces en que sus clientes no le pagan. Tiene planes de poder contar con un almacén donde pueda guardar más cantidad de productos. Este sería el primer crédito con la institución MFP, y se compromete en ser puntual en sus cuotas para así poder acceder a montos mayores de créditos. Con el monto solicitado de 800 nuevos soles, lo invertirá en la compra de maíz en mayores cantidades, sabiendo que así tendrá mejores márgenes de ganancias.
texts.en:
Victoria, 39, is a very hardworking, kind woman.  She lives with her spouse and their four children in her own house that she managed to build with much effort.  Victoria is a merchant dealing in grains like corn.  She acquires it in large volume and then resells it instantly to stores.  She carries out this activity in a river port where she awaits the arrival of the suppliers’ river boat and buys from them at low prices.  

She’s been in this business for a year.  With help from her spouse they seek out new customers.  What she likes about the work is that it produces income to cover household expenses.  She also states that she enjoys dealing with the different people that buy her products.  However, most of her sales are on credit and sometimes some customers don’t pay her.  She plans to have a warehouse where she can store larger amounts of her products.

This would be her first MFP loan and she commits to be punctual with her installment payments so that she can access larger loans.  She will use the 800 new soles requested to buy corn in larger amounts knowing that this will lead to higher profit margins.

loans.use: to buy corn at wholesale.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: Elvira, de 59 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora, además de ser muy alegre, es conviviente con José, vive en compañía de sus dos hijos de 22 y 38 años de edad, a los que quiere mucho, habitando en su propia casa. La actividad que realiza Elvira es la comercialización de abarrote, para esto abrió una pequeña bodega en su propia casa, desde atiende las necesidades de sus vecinos, quienes son sus principales clientes, a los que atiende muy amablemente, desde hace 6 años, tiempo que viene funcionando su bodega. Lo que le gusta de su actividad es el atender al público, con los que socializa y se siente muy a gusto el poder pagarse sus amistades, así se distrae y se siente una mujer productiva, con lo que logra apoyar a su pareja con los gastos del hogar, ya que muchas veces con los ingresos de técnico electricista no les alcanzaba. Considera rentable su negocio gracias a que a ha sabido ganar una regular clientela, que le consumen sus productos, y le da una rotación constante, dejándole las ganancias correspondientes. En la actualidad, dado su edad, considera sola mantener su negocio. Este será el préstamo número 8 con la institución MFP, se siente contenta de poder contar su apoyo con una capital de trabajo, desea seguir contando con este apoyo, por tanto se compromete en cumplir con los pagos de sus cuotas. Con el monto solicitado de 2000 nuevos soles, lo invertirá en la compra de abarrotes de primera necesidad, con los cuales podrá surtir su bodega, así podrá seguir con su negocio.
texts.en: Elvira, 59, is a hard-working, cheerful entrepreneur.  She lives with her common-law husband, José, and their two children, ages 22 and 38, whom they love very much.  They live in their own house.  Elvira sells groceries out of a small store she opened in her home where she receives her neighbors who are her main customers.  She has been in business for six years and is very kind to her customers, since what she enjoys most about her work is being able to socialize with her friends.  She keeps busy and feels she is being productive while helping to cover household expenses, since her husband's income as an electric technician does not always cover costs.  Her business is profitable since she has been able to establish a regular customer base who consume her products regularly meaning inventory turnover is constant and earnings are good.  Her goal now is to keep the business running.  This will be her 8th loan through the MFP institution.  She is grateful for the support and hopes to be able to continue counting on it, and is committed to paying back the loan on time.  The 2,000 PEN loan will be used to buy essential goods to add to the store's inventory to continue operating.

loans.use: To buy essential goods for her store.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 24-year-old married woman with two children who are between the ages of 2 and 4 years old. One of her children is in school. 

Rose has been in the business of selling charcoal in Kator, South Sudan for two years.  She requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more charcoal for resale. She will use her extra income to pay school fees.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Las Gaviotas Group

texts.es:
Luvia cuenta con 31 años de edad, es mama soltera tiene 3 hijos los cuales están estudiando Jesús Iván cursa 1º grado de preparatoria, Crisanta 1º grado de secundaria y Belén  6º grado de primaria.

Ella se dedica al comercio vende comida como son tacos, quesadillas, tostadas, tortas y jugos, cuenta con puesto que tiene en el centro junto al jardín del pueblo, ya tiene 3 años con el negocio dice que le ha funcionado y lo ha sabido sacar adelante ya que con su negocio ayuda con los gastos de su familia y educación de sus hijos, doña Luvia invertirá su préstamo en la compra de los insumos que utiliza para elaborar su comida como son: verduras, teleras, queso,  crema, aceite, etc.

Luvia pertenece al grupo Las Gaviotas el cual está integrado por 11 miembros dos hombres y 9 mujeres a continuación serán mencionados: Juan, Ninfa, Julio, Juana, Estela, Bernabé, Oralia, Nayeli,  Natividad, Santacruz, todos cuentan con una actividad comercial como son: venta de comida, productos de abarrotes, dulces, pescadería, licuados y juegos, verduras, frutas, etc.
texts.en:
Luvia is 31 years old, a single mother of 3 children who are studying. Jesús Iván is in the 1st grade, Crisanta the 7th grade and Belén the 6th grade. Luvia sells food such as tacos, quesadillas, tostadas, tortas and juices. She has her own food stall in the centre of town next to the public gardens. She has been running this business for 3 years and says it is working well and she has known how to make it successful as the income from the business helps her with the family expenses and her children's education.

Doña Luvia will invest the loan in the purchase of ingredients which she will use to make her food such as: vegetables, Mexican flat bread, cheese, cream, oil, etc. Luvia belongs to the group Las Gaviotas which consists of 11 members, 2 men and 9 women who are: Juan, Ninfa, Julio, Juana, Estela, Bernabé, Oralia, Nayeli, Natividad, Santacruz. They all have businesses selling: food, grocery iitems, sweets, fish, shakes and games, vegetables, fruit, etc.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making food such as: vegetables, cheese, cream, tostadas, tortillas, etc.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. 

Lorna has a food shop or sari-sari store that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for two years. She requested a loan of PHP 13,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Lorna has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Lorna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is a mother of four and happily married to Jaime. According to her, she got married when she was 20 years of age. Because she married young, she only finished high school.

Dolores has been running her home-based store for 24 years. She opens her store at 5 o'clock in the morning and she closes it at ten in the evening because she has many customers. She is grateful because through the income generated from her store, she is able sustain her family's needs. She really appreciates her husband's efforts and determination in their agricultural and welding shop businesses to gain extra income for their basic necessities.

Dolores has also been engaged in a pig raising business for 20 years. She is raising one sow and fattening eight pigs. With the businesses she manages, she is able to support her children's education. Nowadays, she is spending her income on her two children who are in college. She hopes to let them finish their degree courses so that they could find good opportunities for their future. She aims to increase her sales to obtain greater profit because she is spending more money on her nine hectares of rice field, pig raising business and education of her two children. With her aim to cover all her expenses, she is asking for additional working capital amounting to P30,000 to be used in buying volumes of merchandise for her home-based store. Through her requested loan she could be able to overcome her struggles in business and most of all she could be generating a bigger income to sustain her family needs and improve her other businesses. She knows that her sacrifices and patience will give her fruitful outcome to become a successful entrepreneur someday.

loans.use: to buy groceries for her home-based store

loans.name: Hai

texts.en: Hai, 30, is married and resides with his wife and one school-aged child in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. He is a distiller. Additionally, he raises pigs to generate more income. His wife is a garment worker. Hai is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase rice to use in wine distilling. By doing so, he would be able to get the rice after distillation to feed his pigs as well. In the future, he plans to expand his distilling business and send his children to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase rice to use in wine distilling

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.en:
Teofilo is a farmer who lives at Capatan. He is married with four children sending to school. He needs to increase his profits due to cost of basic commodities and school expenses now a days is increasing too. He is asking for a loan of P12,000 to buy vitamins, medicines and hog feed for sustainability.

He would like to ensure good nutrition of his hogs so that he can offer it at a higher cost when hogs are ready for disposal. Someday he hopes to make the business grow into a piggery and keep improving sales for additional profits and help finance the college education of his children.

loans.use: to buy vitamins, medicines and hog feed for sustainanbility

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
This is Caroline, a 49-year-old woman who is full of smiles.
She is a woman who has gone through a lot in her life. However, she has always had the strength to overcome it and move forward with her two children. She is very hardworking and a go-getter. She hails from Kiptere, a remote village in the Kericho area of Kenya. 

Her primary sources of income are crops and animal farming. She also gets some income through personal business (shop). Caroline is contented with the farming way of life. 

Caroline is a very enterprising woman, and although she never had formal education or formal employment, she has always worked hard on her farm and she has always assured her children and family a decent meal. The Kiptere  area has favorable conditions for horticulture farming, and that is why she is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start horticulture farming. Because of good roads, a good climate, and a good transportation network, she is sure that she will reap maximum profits and be able to increase her business. 

Accessing funds in Kenya is very challenging, but Caroline feels relieved knowing there are institutions such as Kiva that help enterprising women like her. Caroline is well disciplined with finances and she plans that through the accumulated profits, she will be able to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her children, who are in primary school and high school. 

As the December season is approaching, Caroline wants to close the year on a high note. Please help Caroline so that her horticulture farming can flourish!

loans.use: To buy seeds and start horticulture farming and provide a better income for her two children

loans.name: Nati

texts.en: Nati is 37 years old she is divorced and she takes care of 2 kids Nati lives at her parents house Nati is a farmer and she sells flowers Nati needs a loan to buy chikens for her farm that is located at her parents house she hopes you can help her because she has a lot of experience with animals and she would like to put a flower store in the future

loans.use: to buy chikens for her farm

loans.name: Maira

texts.en:
Maira has about 4 years of experience catching and selling crab. Her husband has been in the industry since he was 12 years when he used to go out and catch crab with his dad. After marrying, Maria’s husband taught her the tricks of the trade and they decided to start a business of their own. They now wake up at 5 am to catch the crabs and work until 2 pm cooking and selling them. Maria is requesting the loan in order to invest in other seafood that she may couple with her crab selling. She is confident that the investment will be worthwhile. Maria is 19 years old and only has one 3 year old son. Her and her husband work very diligently and are hopeful that the loan will help them get ahead.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Invest in other seafood products

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en:
Miss Hoa is a poor lady, 37 years old. Her husband died ago 12 years. Miss Hoa has two children, 14 and 12. Miss Hoa is supporting both her children who are going to school.

She dosesn’t have any land for cultivation so selling folded rice pancakes is important for her family as additional income. This earns about $2/person/month, and their average income is $11/person/month. Now Miss Hoa asks to borrow a loan of $75 for her rice pancake business.

loans.use: Selling folded rice pancakes

loans.name: Khairullo

texts.ru:
Khairullo M. became a client of MicroInvest in 2005. Before joining MicroInvest he sold sweets/candy, cookies etc. Today he sells rice in the ‘Ozodi’ market place. He has been doing this for two years and his business is flourishing. He is married with three children. His wife helps out in his business.

In addition to selling rice, Khairullo also works as a builder, renovating apartments.

Khairullo would like a loan of $867 to increase his inventory and sales, as well as to maximize profits. P.S. The photo is of his wife.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer.

В 2005 г. Мирзоев Хайрулло стал клиентом Микроинвест. До вступления он продавал: конфеты, вафли и т.д. В настоящий момент он занимается продажей риса на рынке «Озоди». В этом бизнесе он уже 2 года, его бизнес процветает. Он женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена помогает ему по бизнесу. Кроме продажи риса Хайрулло занимается ремонтом квартир. Хйрулло хочет получить 867$ для расширения и увеличения товарооборота, а также получения максимальной прибыли. P. S. На фотографии его жена.

loans.use:
Expansion of his business

расширения своего бизнеса

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Mrs. Sum T. is a 31 year widow with one child who lives with her mother (pictured here) in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
